4978;Celebrating 10 years of the landmark tobacco control treaty;celebrating-10-years-of-the-landmark-tobacco-control-treaty;"

column1: The European Region has the highest prevalence of tobacco smoking (28%) among all WHO regions. It has now taken on the challenge of developing a Roadmap of actions for Member States to reduce tobacco use by 30% by the year 2025.

ERS is committed to tobacco control and recently produced the SmokeHaz website (www.smokehaz.eu) – providing evidence from a scientific review of all the respiratory health hazards associated with tobacco smoke.

4983;Celebrating women in ERS - a message from Professor Elisabeth Bel;celebrating-women-in-ers;"

With International Women’s Day taking place this week
column2: this would seem to me the perfect opportunity to take the time to reflect upon the role of women in ERS and highlight the achievements of individuals who have provided inspiration to women in the respiratory field.

column1: I feel honoured to be the first female President of ERS and I am pleased to be taking up the mantle in the knowledge that many successful women have come before me and many more will follow in these footsteps in years to come.
I strongly subscribe to the theme of this year’s International Women’s Day that ‘Empowering Women
column2: Empowering Humanity: Picture it!’ In a speech last year the UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon highlighted the benefits to society as a whole when women are on a level footing. One example he cited is that countries in which higher levels of gender equality exist tend to have better economic growth.1

column1: Historically
column2: the scientific field has been largely dominated by men
column3: but this has begun to change. As we see a more equal gender balance in science
column4: I believe we will see more progress in the field of scientific discovery. By unlocking the scientific potential of many individuals who may not have considered this area of work in previous years
column5: we bring more intellectual minds together to solve the toughest questions in research.

column1: I also believe that by ensuring women are at the forefront of medicine and care
column2: we can bring different life experiences and perspectives together to ensure a diverse workforce is challenging the clinical issues we face on a daily basis. We must continue to encourage women to take on roles in the respiratory field if we are to see the progress we are all working towards.

column1: In the respiratory arena
column2: many influential women have taken on the roles of officers in ERS and other international societies
column3: contributed extensively to research and become leaders in their field.

column1: At the ERS International Congress in Munich last year
column2: we launched the Fellowship of ERS (FERS)
column3: a new accolade that seeks to recognise excellence in the field and to create a body of elite researchers
column4: clinicians and other professionals working in the respiratory arena. 11 women were honoured with the FERS title when the new award launched
column5: and this number is set to increase in the coming years.2

column1: I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the women who have played a role in the success of the Society over the last few years. I also send a message of encouragement to all our female junior members who
column2: together with their male peers
column3: have the future of the Society in their hands. I have no doubt that the combined strengths of both the female and male future leaders of ERS will lead to progress for all.

4991;Antibiotic nanoparticles attack respiratory infection at source and reduce drug side effects;antibiotic-nanoparticles-attack-respiratory-infection-at-source-and-reduce-drug-side-effects;"

 Estoril
column2: Portugal: Treating respiratory disease is often difficult because drugs have to cross biological barriers such as respiratory tissue and mucosa
column3: and must therefore be given in large quantities in order for an effective amount to reach the target. Now researchers from Germany
column4: Brazil and France have shown that the use of nanoparticles to carry antibiotics across biological barriers can be effective in treating lung infections. Doing so allows better delivery of the drug to the site of infection
column5: and hence prevents the development of antibiotic resistance which may be caused by too large and continued doses of antibiotic. Additionally
column6: such a strategy might help to overcome the rapid metabolism and excretion of the antibiotic from the body
column7: which happens when it is administered by traditional routes

column1: Describing her team’s work to the 13th European Respiratory Society Lung Science Conference in Estoril today (Friday)
column2: Dr Cristiane Carvalho-Wodarz
column3: from the Helmholtz Institute for Pharmaceutical Research
column4: Saarbrücken
column5: Germany
column6: will say that
column7: by developing nanoparticles loaded with clarithromycin
column8: an antibiotic commonly used in the treatment of respiratory infections
column9: they have been able to mimick the process that occurs after inhalation in vivo by delivering the drug through aerosol deposition to lung cells. Nanoparticles
column10: which are in the same size range as a virus - millions of times smaller than a tennis ball - were prepared by adding a biodegradable polymer oil
column11: stabiliser and clarithromycin dissolved in solvents
column12: to an aqueous surfactant solution. Subsequently
column13: the solvents were completely removed. “The delivery of nanoparticles in this way enables their deposition in cells cultivated in vitro in a similar way to the deposition in vivo
column14: which take place in the alveoli (air sacs found in the respiratory tract)

column1: The researchers used the bacterium Staphylococcus aureus as the model for their experiment
column2: since it is one of the major causes of hospital-acquired infection and also plays a crucial role in the lung infections which are common in the genetic disorder cystic fibrosis. The tiny clarithromycin nanoparticles (CLARI-NPs)
column3: were able to access the bacteria located either in biofilms (cellssticking to each other on a surface) or inside individual lung cells. “Neither of these locations is conducive to effective drug delivery through traditional routes
column4: ” says Dr Carvalho-Wodarz
column5: “so we were pleased to see that not only did the use of CLARI-NPs allow the uptake of the antibiotic by the lung cells
column6: but also that there were no toxic effects on all the cell types on which we tested.”

column1: To date the work has been in vitro
column2: using human bronchial cells. The researchers now hope to evaluate its effectiveness in an animal model
column3: probably mice. They would also like to test the same nanoparticles loaded with other drugs used against lung infections
column4: and in particular those in which the infectious agent becomes drug-resistant after the continued large doses that may be required.

column1: “Using nanoparticles to deliver drugs to a local site of infection is a promising strategy for overcoming side effects
column2: increasing treatment efficacy
column3: and overcoming resistance. The nanoparticles we have developed have a number of advantages as drug carriers; they do not provoke a toxic effect
column4: they are highly stable
column5: they release the drug over a sustained period
column6: and they can overcome cellular barriers. We believe that our formulation shows promise to improve the antibacterial efficacy which could help patients with lung infections
column7: since the antibiotic can reach the infection site directly and therefore decrease the side effects we see during traditional routes of administration

4992;Researchers uncover a mechanism linking inhaled diesel pollution and respiratory distress;researchers-uncover-a-mechanism-linking-inhaled-diesel-pollution-and-respiratory-distress;"
Estoril
column2: Portugal: Researchers in the UK have
column3: for the first time
column4: shown how exhaust pollution from diesel engines is able to affect nerves within the lung. Air pollution is a significant threat to health
column5: they say
column6:
and identifying potential mechanisms linking exposure to diesel exhaust and the exacerbation of respiratory diseases may lead to treatments for those affected.

Mr. Ryan Robinson
column7: a PhD student at the National Heart and Lung Institute
column10: will tell the 13th European Respiratory Society Lung Science Conference today (Saturday) about his work studying diesel exhaust particles and airway sensory nerves. The news comes as the Healthy Lungs for Life campaign
column11: launched by the European Respiratory Society and European Lung Foundation
column12:
takes places this year aiming to raise awareness of the importance of breathing clean air.

Diesel exhaust is a significant component of urban air pollution
column13: containing a complicated mixture of gases and airborne particles. “Studies have shown that exposure to these diesel particles is associated with harmful health effects
column14: ” says Mr. Robinson. “These particles are very small – down to 20 nanometres in diameter - and are therefore not only invisible to the naked eye
column15:
but can penetrate deep into the lungs.”

The lungs contain numerous sensory nerves that can detect potentially harmful stimuli and thus allow the body to respond
column16: for example by triggering a cough. “However
column17: we know that these nerves can also be involved in exacerbating respiratory conditions
column18: for example by causing the bronchi to constrict in diseases such as asthma
column20: who included Mr. Robinson’s supervisors Professor Maria Belvisi
column21: Professor Terry Tetley and Professor Alexandra Porter
column22: found that the diesel particles from a forklift truck could activate airway sensory nerves in an in vivo anaesthestised guinea pig model. “It was interesting to see that the more chemically sensitive airway nerves were involved
column23: rather than the mechanically sensitive ones
column24:
” says Mr. Robinson.

The researchers then used an in vitro isolated nerve preparation that allowed them to probe the mechanisms involved more rapidly. “The first thing we noted was that the particles
column26: were harmless. It was clear that the chemicals isolated from an organic extraction of the diesel particles were key to the activation of the nerve
column27: which backed up the data we saw in vivo
column28:
” he will tell the conference.

To understand how the diesel extract activated the airway nerves
column29: the researchers used pharmacological and genetic knock out tools. “It is widely known that the environmental sensors known as transient receptor potential (TRP) ion channels are key to airway sensory nerve activation
column30: so we decided to block a variety of different channels to discover whether an extract of diesel could activate any of them
column31:
” he will say.

The researchers found that the responses to the diesel extract were driven by activation of the TRP ankryin-1 (TRPA1) channel. They also discovered that the application of an antioxidant abolished the responses to the extract. “Oxidative stress
column32: an imbalance between disturbances in the normal oxidative state of cells and the system's ability to repair the resulting damage
column33: is linked to many diseases and is a known TRPA1 activator
column36: only a first step towards understanding how air pollution may be affecting airway sensory nerves and respiratory reflexes. Whether other types of fuel activate airway nerves remains to be seen
column37: and it is even possible that they may have a far more potent effect in this area than diesel. It will also be crucial to determine whether increased activation of sensory nerves explains why some are more susceptible to the effects of air pollution than others
column38:
the researchers say.

“We hope that our work may lead to treatments or management strategies than can help those with respiratory diseases such as asthma that are particularly affected by air pollution
column39: ” says Mr. Robinson. “Our results indicate that our reliance on fossil fuels
column41: could have a detrimental effect on our health
column42: supporting the idea that we should be looking towards alternative fuel sources. We believe that our data highlight an important alternative mechanism by which diesel contributes to respiratory illness and will further influence governments in the quest to initiate change
column43:
” he will conclude.

Experts have developed a process using specially-treated krypton gas as an inhalable contrast agent to make the spaces inside the lungs show up on a Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan. It is hoped the new process will eventually allow doctors to virtually see inside the lungs of patients.

column2: xenon
column3: or krypton possible in a single breath hold by the patient. In the new paper
column4: researchers have developed a technique to generate hyperpolarised krypton gas at high purity
column5: a step that will significantly facilitate the use of this new contrast agent for pulmonary MRI.

column1: Author of the paper
column2: Professor Thomas Meersmann from the Sir Peter Mansfield Imaging Centre at Nottingham University in the UK
column3: said: ""It is particularly demanding to retain the hyperpolarized state of krypton during preparation of this contrast agent. We have solved a problem by using a process that is usually associated with clean energy related sciences. It's called catalytic hydrogen combustion. Bacterial biomarkers that predict early treatment success in tuberculosis cases have been identified in a new study published in BMC Medicine. The findings could have positive implications for both treatment time and costs moving forward.

There were 9 million new cases and 1.5 million deaths from TB in 2013 and predictive biomarkers for treatment efficacy are essential to help understand how the bacilli persists through treatment in drug-resistant strains of the infection.
The study used genome-wide transcriptional profiling to map mRNA signatures of Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli (M.tb). The sputa of 15 patients were analysed before and 3
column2: 7 and 14 days after the start of standard regimen drug treatment to understand why some bacteria survive through months of drug treatment.

column1: The study showed for the first time that by testing patients' sputum
column2: specific changes could be identified in M.tb two weeks after starting drug therapy that could predict the success of treatment six weeks later.

column1: Dr. Simon Waddell
column2: working with a team of researchers from the UK
column3: South Africa and Finland said of the discovery: ""Profiling TB bacteria in this way may help find predictive markers of treatment success that are desperately needed in clinical trials and in the clinic. This would reduce the cost of drug trials needed to test new drugs for TB
column4: and allow doctors to quickly stratify patients who are not responding to drug therapy.""

column1: Asthma is a chronic lung disease and is a major noncommunicable respiratory disease. It affects millions of people all around the world and reduces their quality of life by limiting physical activity or contributing to lost school or work days. Asthma is common in adults and children in both high- and low-income countries.

column2: World Asthma Day reinforces the new important United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals
column3: which include plans to reduce premature mortality from noncommunicable diseases by one-third
column4: through prevention and treatment. According to the 2014 Global Asthma Report
column5: avoidable asthma deaths are due to a failure to implement prevention strategies.

column1: To achieve this goal in asthma
column2: stakeholders must collaborate locally and globally to ensure adequate funding and resources are available to implement effective preventative and therapeutic strategies for this common disease.

column1: The causes of asthma are not fully understood
column2: risk factors include a genetic predisposition along with triggers
column3: such as exposure to substances that irritate the air passages and cause allergic reactions. These include dust
column4: pets
column5: tobacco smoke
column6: chemicals and air pollution. Other causes are physical exercise
column7: certain medications
column8: cold air and even emotions. In severe cases
column9: asthma can also be fatal; and sadly most asthma-related deaths occur in low- and lower-middle income countries. Asthma is also expensive
column10: accounting for significant health care costs. In Europe
column11: the total cost of asthma in 2011 was estimated at €19.3 billion among Europeans aged from 15 to 64 years.

column2: asthma can be treated effectively.

column1:
• Effective management of asthma helps people to enjoy a good quality of life;
• Avoiding asthma triggers can reduce the severity of asthma;
• Medications can help control asthma;
• Long-term preventer medicines help reduce airway inflammation and symptoms;
• Reliever medications provide quick relief of acute asthma symptoms; and
• Knowledge and education are key to controlling asthma
column2: and the more people know about the disease
column3: the more effectively they can manage it.

column1: Asthma is a major public health issue. Working together
column2: health professionals and people with asthma can prevent
column3: treat and manage asthma effectively in order to avoid negative health effects. Resources should be used optimally to ensure all people with asthma have access to effective education
column4: prevention and medications.

column1: Leaders in respiratory health must unite globally to invest in community-led solutions to improve the quality of life and reduce morbidity and mortality in asthma. FIRS calls on countries and organizations around the world to invest and take necessary actions to encourage people-centred prevention
column2: treatment and care to ensure that every person with asthma has access to high-value care.

5260;Study identifies lung cancer mutations that may be responsive to immunotherapy;study-identifies-lung-cancer-mutations-that-may-be-responsive-to-immunotherapy;"

A new study has identified a number of new driver mutations in lung cancer cells that may be responsive to genomically targeted therapies and to immunotherapy.
The research
column2: recently published in Nature Genetics
column3: examined 1
column4: 144 genome profiles of cancers from people with either lung adenocarcinoma or lung squamous cell carcinoma to identify new drivers of lung carcinogenesis.

column1: Of the 58 significantly mutated genes found in the cancers
column2: only 6 mutated genes were shared by both types
column3: which highlighted that the two cancers differ significantly from each other despite arising in the same organ.

column1: The study also identified several predicted neoepitopes that may act as markers to both identify and treat lung cancer. 47% of lung adenocarcinoma and 53% of lung squamous cell carcinoma samples had at least 5 predicted neoepitopes. These figures suggest good prospects for immunotherapy
column2: which has potential advantages over radiotherapy and chemotherapy because in principle it spares the healthy cells.

column1: Lead author of the paper Joshua Campbell
column2: postdoctoral associate at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard
column3: noted: ""We have identified several distinct recurrent mutations that are likely to be recognised by the immune system and therefore would be strong candidates for cancer vaccines.”

column1: Campbell added that ""Future studies are needed to determine what allows a mutation in a gene to cause uncontrolled growth in one type of cell but not in another type. This knowledge will give us a more complete understanding of the molecular pathways involved in tumor growth and help us design better drugs.""
The data obtained in the study have been deposited into the most complete database of genetic alterations in cancer cells - the Catalogue Of Somatic Mutations In Cancer (COSMIC).
